termEntry.descrip: a computer program designed for a specific task or use
to add a component or device to a system while the system is off

situation where a computer must be powered down in order to add or remove a component or to allow a device to synchronize data with the computer. Cold plugging is often used as an additional precaution to ensure a component is not damaged while being removed or replaced.
The layer above the back-end which includes all software or hardware that is part of a user interface
Refers to parts of a computer application or a program's code that allow it to operate and that cannot be accessed by a user
A feature that allows equipment to be connected to an active device, such as a computer, while the device is powered on. Commonly used for non-RAID devices. For RAID devices, use hotswap.
The process of replacing a component in a system without shutting down or interrupting its operation. Commonly used for non-RAID devices. For RAID devices, use hotswapping.

GUI element that is a list whose entries each start an action. Superordinate concept of drop-down list There are different types of menus like text-based menu, pictorial menu, drop-down or pop-up menu
A prewritten list of commands, and perhaps other control information, to be executed (interpreted) by a shell or other command interpreter
describes a standardized client–server environment that boots a software assembly, retrieved from a network, on PXE-enabled clients.
An instruction to a computer program that, when issued by the user, causes an action to be carried out.

a modular printing system for Unix-like computer operating systems which allows a computer to act as a print server. A computer running CUPS is a host that can accept print jobs from client computers, process them, and send them to the appropriate printer.

tig.term: 通用 Unix 打印系统

termEntry.descrip: Any character or series of characters that represent horizontal or vertical space in typography
A service like socket, device, mount point, timer, etc. managed by systemd.
Configuration file of a systemd unit. The suffix defines the unit type like [.service], [.socket], etc.
an interface between two binary program modules. It defines how data structures or computational routines are accessed in machine code.
command line tool that enables communication with an emulator instance or connected Android-powered device.
To retroactively supply a fix, or a new feature, to a previous version of a software product at the same time (or after) supplying it to the current version
A change to a system or product to handle programming issues that are found and resolved during production or testing phases or even after deployment as part of the normal release cycle of a product
The process of logging and monitoring bugs or errors during software testing
A record of all (historical) changes made to a project
A small-sized block of data derived from another block of digital data for the purpose of detecting errors that may have been introduced during its transmission or storage
a list of digital certificates that have been revoked by the issuing certificate authority (CA) before their actual or assigned expiration date
The process of returning production to its original location after a disaster or a scheduled maintenance period
The process of switching production to a backup facility (normally your recovery site)
A specialized electronic circuit designed to manipulate and alter memory to accelerate the creation of images in a frame buffer intended for output to a display device
A 128-bit number for a file system that is unique on both the local system and across other systems.

The process of securing a system by reducing its surface of vulnerability, which is larger when a system performs more functions; in principle a single-function system is more secure than a multipurpose one.
A periodic signal generated by hardware or software to indicate normal operation or to synchronize other parts of a computer system
A specific location that provides Internet access via a wireless local area network (WLAN)
A file holding the contents of memory at the point when a program crashed, possibly useful in debugging

A set of properties of a concurrent system that require a system to make progress despite the fact that its concurrently executing components ("processes") may have to "take turns" in critical sections, parts of the program that cannot be simultaneously run by multiple processes
The routing of a signal, data stream, etc. from its origin back to the origin, primarily as a means of testing the transmission or transportation infrastructure
The process or act of containing the impact and/or risk from an attack.
The communication between a single sender and multiple receivers on a network
A technique that allows defining multiple physical connections between a server and its storage arrays
(of a computer) capable of being used by several people at once
a computer hardware component that connects a computer to a computer network
a menu on various devices that provides options used to adjust the display or other options available to that device
the operation of reading data from a storage medium in advance so that it is immediately available when requested
A mechanism to allow software to execute a remote procedure

a testing environment that isolates untested code changes and outright experimentation from the production environment or repository, in the context of software development including Web development, Automation and revision control.
A commitment between a service provider and a client
A type of mass storage that does not depend on mechanical parts

The protocol for establishing authenticated and encrypted links between networked computers. Predecessor of TLS (Transport Layer Security). Although the SSL protocol was deprecated with the release of TLS 1.0 in 1999, it is still common to refer to these related technologies as “SSL” or “SSL/TLS.”
A memory cache that stores recent translations of virtual memory to physical addresses for faster retrieval
a category of cloud computing that supplies an on-demand environment for software development over the Internet.
A software package that provides an entire runtime environment: an application, plus its dependencies, system libraries, settings and other binaries, and the configuration files needed to run it
Coordination of automated cloud computing tasks, resulting in a consolidated workflow.
The process of using virtual machine templates and configuration tools to set up and deploy cloud computing workloads
A software distribution model in which a cloud provider hosts applications and makes them available to end users over the Internet
The ability for IT systems – such as applications, storage, databases and networking – to continue to function properly when changed in size or volume

Combines software-defined compute (SDC), software-defined networking (SDN) and software-defined storage (SDS) into a fully software-defined data center (SDDC). The SDI model allows many critical IT functions to be fully integrated and automated, such as backups and data recovery.

A computer platform that creates a centralized and programmable logical network. It means separating the system that controls where traffic is sent (the control plane) from the underlying system that forwards traffic to the selected destination (the data plane, also called the forwarding plane). This means that the functions previously fulfilled by a single, usually inflexible switch can now be separated between a switch (data plane) and its controller (control plane). In this model, the controller is programmable and can be very flexible and adapt quickly to changing network conditions.
A software development approach where developers regularly merge or integrate code changes into a central repository.
An iterative software development approach that ensures every change to a system can be released
The foundation of the Linux computer operating system. A kernel is the lowest level of software that can interface with computer hardware.
A high-capacity computer that often serves as the central data repository in an organization’s IT infrastructure

A state of continuous operation in a computer system or IT component for a specified length of time. High availability may also refer to an agreed level of operational performance (usually uptime) assured for a higher than normal period.
A computer industry term for the time during which a computer or IT system is unavailable, offline or not operational
A set of connected computers (nodes) that work together as if they are a single (much more powerful) machine
Any IT component (software, hardware, database, process, application, etc.) that performs a function essential to business operations (also known as a mission-critical system)
The IT practice of aggregating computing power to deliver more performance than a typical computer can provide
A software development approach in which every code change goes through the entire pipeline and is put into production automatically, resulting in many production deployments every day.
A computer with a high level of performance compared to a general-purpose computer

Proprietary software - computer software for which the software's publisher or another person reserves some licensing rights to use, modify, share modifications, or share the software, restricting user freedom with the software they lease
infrastructure that is designed to support rapid deployment and provisioning, and incremental upgrades and improvements

tig.term: 敏捷的 IT 基础架构

termEntry.descrip: A family of reduced instruction set computer (RISC) instruction set architectures for computer processors, configured for various environments.
An integrated chip or circuit that combines all of the various components of a computer or other system
A board-level circuit that integrates a system function in a single module
The ability of an organization to maintain its essential functions during and after a disaster
The capability for different IT systems and devices to exchange data and process or use the exchanged data, regardless of its source
A connected array of Linux computers or nodes that work together and can be viewed and managed as a single system
The communication between an information processing system, such as a computer, and the outside world, possibly a human or another information processing system
A type of IT storage typically used in storage area network (SAN) environments (also called block-level storage)
A dedicated high-speed computer network that connects storage devices with servers
A type of IT storage for unstructured, non-hierarchical data (such as email messages, documents, videos, graphics, audio files and web pages) known as objects (also called object-based storage)
A software-defined storage solution that distributes data across clusters of storage resources
A type of IT storage for storing data in a hierarchical structure (also called file-level or file-based storage)
A storage-as-a-service model that remotely stores, manages, backs up and shares data over the Internet
A type of cloud computing that combines public and private clouds, with integration, management and orchestration between the public and private platforms
A deployment model where Cloud Services are controlled and used exclusively by the user/customer.

A type of cloud computing that provides storage, compute and networking services to a single organization in an Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) model; also known as internal cloud or corporate cloud
a networking approach that decouples network functions from dedicated hardware, enabling them to run as software on standard IT infrastructure for greater agility and efficiency
delays in data communication over a network
A guaranteed level of computer responsiveness within a specified time constraint, usually milliseconds or microseconds, between an event and its response deadline
A computer industry term for the time during which a computer or IT system is operational
A script that automatically creates Linux containers on the Docker platform

An operating system paradigm in which the kernel allows the existence of multiple isolated user space instances, called containers, zones, virtual private servers, partitions, virtual environments, virtual kernels, or jails
small program that places the operating system (OS) of a computer into memory.
The growing network of non-computing devices that are engineered to be able to connect and exchange data over the internet
Devices that are configured to be available for passthrough and are bound to a suitable PCI back-end driver rather than a real driver.

In the UNIX environment, Kerberos scopes of deployment are called realms. A realm is somewhat similar to a domain in a Windows network. Users belong to specific realms and they authenticate to their respective realms just as Windows network users authenticate to the domains of which they are members. The KDC and the services and applications that use Kerberos make up the realm.
A program you run to install a software on your machine. The program's filename can be setup.exe or install.exe
Interfaces or formats that are openly documented and have been accepted in the industry through either formal or de facto processes, and which are freely available for adoption by the industry.

Man page is short for manual page, which is a type of electronic or software documentation usually found in Unix and Unix-like operating systems. It provides users with detailed documentation for included software programs, system commands, formal standards and conventions, and operating system nuances such as system and library calls. The man page is usually invoked through the command "man," followed by the object, command name or topic, e.g., "man shell."
process of combining one image with a background to create the appearance of partial or full transparency

The original file compression program for UNIX/Linux. Recent versions produce files with a .gz extension. (A .z or .Z extension indicates an older version of Gzip.) Compression is used to compact files to save storage space and reduce transfer time. (When combined with Tar, the resulting file extensions may be .tgz, .tar.gz or .tar.Z.)
A single file containing one or more other archived and, optionally, compressed files. The tool Tape ARchive is widely used for packaging files.
A Linux daemon that executes specified tasks at a designated time or interval.
Development community in charge of producing a more useful and more bug-free product for everyone, especially because more people will be reviewing the code.
Redhat Package Manager. The RPM is used by many Linux distributions, not only Redhat, to hold all files and data about a package together in one file (.rpm).

An operating system based around the Linux kernel. Linux distributions are available in many combinations of components. Each distribution reflects either the needs of its target market, in the case of the commercial distributions or the wishes of its developers, as is the case with distributions created by individuals or non-profit organizations.
Environment that will handle collaboration, devices, wireless, thin clients, authentication, all tied to the Linux server.

a protocol that stands for FIles transferred over SHell and its original implementation was developed by Pavel Machek for the Midnight Commander file manager. The KDE project incorporated into their Konqueror file manager/web browser with the advent of version 3.1.
A set of requirements and guidelines for file and directory locations under UNIX-like operating systems.

tig.term: 文件系统层次结构标准

termEntry.descrip: A collection of objects laid on top of each other and presented in the desktop.
The ~ symbol. Used by several shells and other programs to represent a users home directory.

an enhancement of virtualization technology in which a guest OS is recompiled prior to installation inside a virtual machine. Paravirtualization allows for an interface to the virtual machine that can differ somewhat from that of the underlying hardware. This capacity minimizes overhead and optimizes system performance by supporting the use of virtual machines that would be underutilized in conventional or full virtualization.
Paravirtualized Linux is an operating system that has been modified to run in a virtualized environment.

tig.term: 半虚拟化 Linux 操作系统

termEntry.descrip: To extract files from a Tape Archive (tar).
special file used on many Unix-like operating systems to facilitate transparent communication between user space applications and computer hardware.
To monitor an input/output interface (e.g. a port) for incoming communication
Flushes a device, and stops all programs that are using it. Reverse operation of mount.
An object or item placed at the root level of a hierarchy.
The shell that is started when you log into the system.
The interval at which the display on a monitor is refreshed.

A security device given to authorized users who keep them in their possession. To log onto the network, the security "card" or "token" is read directly like a credit card, or it displays a changing number that is typed in as a password.

Efficiently directing power to different components of a system. Power management is especially important for portable devices that rely on battery power. By reducing power to components that aren't being used, a good power management system can double or triple the lifetime of a battery.
a computer's button for Power on/off, Sleep, Lid Open or Lid Closed action

the hardware, software, and services center. The majority of the components are wizards, leading the user through the configuration processes. The left panel is the directory, while the right is the main services panel.
The partition where / (the root directory) will be located on a UNIX or UNIX-compatible system.
an instance of a computer program, consisting of one or more threads, that is being sequentially executed by a computer system that has the ability to run several computer programs concurrently.
A computer program called daemon runs in the background, rather than under the direct control of a user, and manages the router system logging operation.

The processing of software interrupts sent to a program to indicate that an important event has occurred. The events can vary from user requests to illegal memory access errors. Some signals, like the interrupt signal, indicate that a user has asked the program to do something that is not in the usual flow of control.

A collection of rules and data specific to a spoken and/or written language and/or a geographic area. Locale information includes human languages, date and time formats, numeric and monetary conventions, sorting rules, cultural and regional contexts (semantics), and character classification.
A program used to start another program.
set of permissions associated with every file and directory that determine who can read it, write to it, or execute it. Only the owner of the file (or the super-user) can change these permissions.

In BSD-style print systems, a file that holds the configuration information; the printing daemon reads this file to determine which printers are available, what filters are to be used for each, where the spooling folder is located, if there are banner pages to be used, and so on.

the process where mounting and unmounting of certain filesystems is done automatically by a daemon. If the filesystem is unmounted, and a user attempts to access it, it will be automatically (re)mounted.
any process started by the user that is running in a Linux environment background.
A utility that controls the network packet filtering code in the Linux kernel.
A mode that provides the ability to boot a small Linux environment entirely from a diskette or CD-ROM, or by using some other method.
A system used for accessing your Linux partitions from the outside in the event of an emergency. The rescue system can be loaded from CD, the network, or the SUSE FTP server.
The graphical interface used on Linux systems and applications. It is the middle layer between the hardware and a window manager such as KDE or GNOME.
One of the two types of AppArmor rules that specifies what a process can access in the file system. By default, AppArmor limits the capabilities a process is given
include statements that are grouped by common application tasks. See also program chunks and tunables.
Rules and regulations regarding a specific activity, behavior or other aspect of the system or software. Policies are contained in license certificates.
is where a file in one directory acts as a pointer to a file in another directory.
The credit scheduler is a fair-share scheduler that allocates virtual CPUs to physical CPUs based on the workload in each domain.
Dialog that requests authentication data from the user.
error message that appears when the user has run a command for which the user does not have the execute permission rights
XenSource Inc. for virtual machine interoperability between its hypervisor and the Xen open source virtualization platform.

A software appliance is a software application combined with an unmodified or purpose-built operating system such as a file server or application server. The application runs on top of the operating system. In some cases, software appliance vendors may install the software appliance on a piece of hardware prior to delivery to the customer. Thus the appliance is enterprise ready because the software is maintained and supported by the software appliance vendor. See also virtual appliance.

Journaled File System or JFS is a 64-bit journaling filesystem created by IBM. It is available under the GNU GPL. There are versions for AIX, eComStation, OS/2 and Linux operating systems. HP-UX has another, different filesystem named JFS that is actually an OEM version of Veritas Software's VxFS.

Linux for Mainframes is the server consolidation alternative that delivers the resiliency of a mainframe, the power of SUSE Linux Enterprise Server for System z and the hypervisor capabilities of z/VM.
Companies that develop products based on Linux source code.
AutoYaST is a system for unattended deployment of Linux systems.

culmination of all the configurations, packages and user-space uniqueness kept in a concise, standards-based XML file. This file can be plugged into a build scenario and used repeatedly to provision devices.
A server used to build software from source code. A build server can also host builds for distribution and installation to desktops in a network

a snapshot which contains not only the OS but any additional components and configuration (System management, Monitoring, Backup, Volume management, Security, High availability, Integration with storage and network infrastructure), and as such it has been engineered and tested as a single cohesive unit which is not only internally self-consistent, but also whose functionality aligns correctly with the infrastructure environment in which it will be deployed.
method to evaluate the customer's requirements and use cases
In a template-based install, a base image can be combined with various parts of a template which can provide certain personalities to a server.
an XML file that contains all or most of the required values to perform an unattended installation of SUSE Linux Enterprise Server

Rules offer the possibility to configure a system depending on system attributes by merging multiple control file during installation. Rules-based installation is controlled by a rules file. The rules file is an XML based file that contains rules for each group of systems (or single systems) that you want to automatically install. A set of rules distinguishes a group of systems based on one or more system attributes. After passing all rules, it links each group of rules to a profile. Both the rules file and the profiles must be located in a predefined and accessible location.
a customized media containing the installation image to perform an offline installation of a software

Maintenance updates do not change versions of software and never change external interfaces, so limited testing (basically unit testing) is enough, with all the automated regression testing in the build system.

tig.term: SUSE Linux Enterprise 维护模型

termEntry.descrip: This script executes after the install has begun but has not read the AutoYaST control file. This script is useful for modifying the control file based on system attributes or configure some piece of hardware before the installation begins.
Runs after the second stage of the install has completed but before any network access is enabled.

One of AppArmor's operating modes, the other one being complain mode or learning mode. Profiles loaded in enforcement mode will result in enforcement of the policy defined in the profile as well as reporting policy violation attempts to syslogd.
A static Web page that is designed, coded, and written for optimal search engine and directory positioning.
Data structure that contains information about files in a UNIX or UNIX-compatible file system.

any program whose source code is made available for use or modification as users or other developers see fit. Open Source is a certification mark owned by the Open Source Initiative (OSI). Developers of software that is intended to be freely shared and possibly improved and redistributed by others can use the Open Source trademark if their distribution terms conform to the OSI's Open Source Definition.

An AppArmor profile applies to an executable program, but if a portion of the program needs different access permissions than other portions, the program can “change hats” to use a different security context, distinctive from the access of the main program. This is known as a hat or subprofile.
A type of login script that sets the environment for multiple users in one or more groups. It is a property of a Profile object. Only one profile script is allowed per user.
method employed by redundant arrays of inexpensive disks (RAID) in which a single unit of data is distributed across several hard disks, increasing resistance to a failure in one of the drives.

A control file for the shell, especially a text file automatically that reads from each user's home directory and intended to be easily modified by the user in order to customise the program's behaviour.
a unique key to encrypt or decrypt files and messages
A file showing the structure of a program after it has been compiled. The map file lists every variable in the program along with its memory address.

a system for annotating a text in a way which is syntactically distinguishable from that text. Markup is typically omitted from the version of the text which is displayed for end-user consumption. Some markup languages, like HTML have presentation semantics, meaning their specification prescribes how the structured data is to be presented, but other markup languages, like XML, have no predefined semantics.
the number of times the server is being replicated

in LDAP sync a “provider” is the source of updates and a “consumer” is the openldap which is to be updated. There are various models for ldap sync, in its simple version all the data for all records are copied when there is a change but there are more sophisticated models which only copy the changes. This can be useful if you have a large directory.

A standalone server has only its own database of end users, and it processes logon requests by itself. It does not share account information with any other computer and cannot provide access to domain accounts.
the master server (provider) in a replication setup.
Replication consumer (Slave). Setup of an OpenLDAP slave server that replicates all its data, including configuration, from a master server.
An authentication mechanism that is supported by most browsers. Basic authentication encodes (but does not encrypt) user name and password data before transmitting it over the network.
Keymaps are keyboard table descriptions for keyboard translation tables (loadkeys and dumpkeys), i.e. they point to different keys for different languages.

The IP Masquerade is a form of Network Address Translation or NAT which NAT allows internally connected computers that do not have one or more registered Internet IP addresses to communicate to the Internet via the Linux server's Internet IP address.

a configuration of multiple physical hard-drives to form logical arrays and volumes. Operating Systems recognise this storage as a volume and not independent disks. The aim of RAID configuration is to provide fault tolerance without compromising on performance. RAID has different levels of configuration depending on the type of data-mirroring required and the number of physical disks intended to be employed.

A process in an X Window System which controls a bitmap display device and usually also a keyboard and mouse or other pointing device. The X server performs operations on request from client applications, which may be on the same computer or a different computer connected via the network.
Panic is what Unix does when a critical internal consistency check fails in such a way that Unix cannot continue.

One of the two modes of migration with QEMU/KVM and libvirt. With plain migration, the source host VM opens a direct unencrypted TCP connection to the destination host for sending the migration data. Unless a port is manually specified, libvirt will choose a migration port in the range 49152-49215, which will need to be open in the firewall on the remote host. Compare with tunneled migration.

One of the two modes primary types of migration with QEMU/KVM and libvirt. With tunneled migration, the source host libvirtd opens a direct connection to the destination host libvirtd for sending migration data. This allows the option of encrypting the data stream. Compare with plain migration.

an image file containing a root file system image which is loaded by the kernel and mounted from /dev/ram as the temporary root file system. Mounting this file system requires a file system driver. Beginning with kernel 2.6.13, the initrd has been replaced by the initramfs (initial RAM file system), which does not require a file system driver to be mounted. ⇾SUSE Linux Enterprise Server⇽ exclusively uses an initramfs. However, since the initramfs is stored as /boot/initrd, it is often called “initrd”.
One of seven full-screen terminal displays on Linux that are accessed by pressing Ctrl+Alt+Fn, where n is the number of the terminal you want.
In a Linux interface (e.g in the YaST installation workflow), a full screen without frame. Contrast with dialog box.
One of 3 AppArmor's classes of #includes, program chunks are include statements that contain chunks of profiles that are specific to program suites. See also abstractions and tunables.

One of 3 AppArmor's classes of #includes, tunables are global variable definitions. When used in a profile, these variables expand to a value that can be changed without changing the entire profile. Therefore your profiles become portable to different environments. See also abstractions and program chunks.
Virtual appliances are software appliances specifically created to run on top of virtualization platforms.
A purchase that is made by a signed order to services with a well-defined duration.
computer platform that creates a virtualized network of storage resources by separating the management software from its underlying storage hardware
A software repository is a storage location from which software packages may be retrieved and installed on a computer.
An applet that informs you about the availability of patches and lets you easily install them with just a few clicks.

Update repositories contain package updates that together form patches. Your customers can easily update their installed systems through the update patches. Basically, there are two types of update repositories: production update repositories and testing update repositories. By default, one production and one testing update repository is available for each adapted appliance. These two repositories cannot be deleted. Contrast with pool repository.

An update repository that is created automatically and that is always present for each enabled appliance. It normally provides standard update patches. Each appliance can only have one production repository. Contrast with testing update repository
An update repository for testing purposes. Contrast with production update repository.
A repository with no updated packages. Contrast with update repository.
A feature you use to manage configured software repositories and services.
A catalog of updates for your environment

A delta RPM consists only of the binary diff between two defined versions of a package, and therefore has the smallest download size. Before being installed, the full RPM package is rebuilt on the local machine.

refers to the original project, author or maintainer of a software that is distributed as source code. Feedback, patches, feature enhancements, or other improvements flow from end users or contributors to upstream developers. They decide if it will be integrated or rejected. (compare it with downstream).

people or organisations who integrate the source code from upstream with other software to build a distribution which is then used by end users. Thus, the software flows downstream from its developers via the integrators to the end users.
a compressed file in rpm format that contains all files for a particular program, including optional components like configuration, examples, and documentation.
A periodically released, installable collection of updates, fixes, and code enhancements.
A short interval of time allotted to each user or program in a multitasking or timesharing system. Time slices are typically in milliseconds.

Slices are when the SSSD ID-mapping algorithm takes a range of available UIDs and divides it into equally-sized component sections. Those component sections are called slices. Each slice represents the space available to an Active Directory domain. See also time slice
A feature that allows SSSD to act as a client of Active Directory without requiring administrators to extend user attributes to support POSIX attributes for user and group identifiers.
the default policy to use when CUPS fails to send a print job to the printer device.

The booth is the instance managing the ticket distribution and thus, the failover process between the sites of a multi-site cluster. Each of the participating clusters and arbitrators runs a service, the boothd. It connects to the booth daemons running at the other sites and exchanges connectivity details.

Arbitrators are single machines that run a booth instance in a special mode. As all booth instances communicate with each other, arbitrators help to make more reliable decisions about granting or revoking tickets.
The IP address of the arbitrator.
In a cluster environment, expected votes is a value that is used to determine quorum. The cluster is quorate if the sum of votes of existing members is over half of the expected votes value.
an open-source high availability resource manager software used on computer clusters

Clusters of physical servers which are operated with a network signal latency greater than 15 milliseconds. The sites communicate via IP. The sites communicate via IP. Failover across the sites is coordinated by a higher-level entity. Geo clusters need to cope with limited network bandwidth and high latency. Storage is replicated asynchronously.

A single cluster in one location (for example, all nodes are located in one data center). The cluster uses multicast or unicast for communication between the nodes and manages failover internally. Network latency can be neglected. Storage is typically accessed synchronously by all nodes.
A single cluster that can stretch over multiple buildings or data centers, with all sites connected by fibre channel. Network latency is usually low (<5 ms for distances of approximately 20 miles).
A firewall mark is a way of aggregating an arbitrary collection of VIP:port services into one virtual service.

The kernel determines which processes require more cpu time than others by the process' nice level, also called niceness. The higher the nice level of a process is, the less CPU time it will take from other processes. Nice levels range from -20 (the least “nice” level) to 19.

In computing, the process identifier (normally referred to as the process ID or just PID) is a number used by most operating system kernels — such as that of UNIX, Mac OS X or Microsoft Windows — to uniquely identify an active process. This number may be used as a parameter in various function calls, allowing processes to be manipulated, such as adjusting the process's priority or killing it altogether.
A golden image is a template for a virtual machine (VM), virtual desktop, server or hard disk drive.

A background program that runs unattended, collecting information or performing operating system administration tasks. Some daemons are triggered automatically by events; others operate at timed intervals.
an installable list of packages needed for a special purpose.
A local or remote directory containing packages plus additional information about these packages (package meta-data).
A generic term for product, pattern, package or patch. The most commonly used type of resolvable is a package or a patch.
Installation of a newer minor version of a package.
A patchrpm consists only of files that have been updated since it was first released for openSUSE 11.1. Its download size is usually considerably smaller than the size of a package.

an (external) device that can switch off a computer (in case the computer ‘hangs’, for example). And the device should be backed up by battery (so it still works in case of a power outage and can reliably switch off the computer).
automatically mount file systems at the time they are accessed, and also unmount them later
A supplementary product that provides additional functionality when used with a prerequisite underlying base product.
A duplicate of a program, a disk, or data, made either for archiving purposes or for safeguarding files.
A group of interdependent motherboard chips or integrated circuits that control the flow of data and instructions between the central processing unit (CPU) or microprocessor and external devices

A TCP/IP service protocol that helps to assign network settings centrally (from a server) rather than configuring them locally on every workstation. A host configured to use DHCP does not have control over its own static address.
An object in a filesystem that contains files and other directories.
hierarchical and decentralized naming system used to identify computers, services, and other resources reachable through the Internet or other Internet Protocol (IP) networks
a portion of random-access memory (RAM) containing a bitmap that drives a video display

A member of the TCP/IP suite of protocols, used to copy files between two computers on the Internet. Both computers must support their respective FTP roles: one must be an FTP client and the other an FTP server.
An interface which employs graphical images, widgets and text to represent the information and actions available to the user
An inflexible platter coated with material in which data can be recorded magnetically with read/write heads.
a directory entry (in a directory-based file system) that associates a name with a file

a virtualization platform that allows multiple operating systems to execute on a single host computer. Its primary job is to provide isolated execution environments and to control access to the underlying hardware resources.
discontinued 64-bit instruction set architecture (ISA) developed by Intel
electromagnetic radiation (EMR) with wavelengths longer than those of visible light
a shell script run by init to tart an application on boot time and stop on shutdown
The process of assigning initial values to variables and data structures in a program.
a storage medium (e.g. USB flash drive or DVD) where the installation files of a software is copied to in order to install this software on a device
source of installation data for products, can be a physical medium or online repository

the first version of the Internet Protocol (IP) as a standalone specification. It is one of the core protocols of standards-based internet working methods in the Internet and other packet-switched networks. An IPv4 address consists of 32 bits. Its successor, IPv6 offers 128 bit.
Writing information to a journal (log) file as a method of tracking changes.

A modern computer operating system usually segregates virtual memory into kernel space and user space. Primarily, this separation serves to provide memory protection and hardware protection from malicious or errant software behaviour.
a series of development and support stages that a product passes through
a hostname that refers to the current device used to access it
A file that stores messages generated by an application, service, or operating system that are used to track the operations performed.
e-mail format; common way of storing email messages in which each message is stored in a separate file with a unique name, and each mail folder is a file system directory.
a file formats used for holding collections of email messages

A workstation directory to which you mount a file system that exists on a remote machine. The mount point, a directory in the currently accessible filesystem (typically an empty directory) becomes synonymous with the root directory of the subtree from the new drive, and the original contents of the mount point becomes invisible and inaccessible until the filesystem is dismounted.

A form of processing supported by most current operating systems in which a computer works on multiple tasks-roughly, separate "pieces" of work-seemingly at the same time by parceling out the processor's time among the different tasks.
A server that maintains information about a portion of the DNS database and that responds to and resolves DNS queries.
a declarative region that provides a scope to the identifiers (the names of types, functions, variables, etc) inside it
A text string that specifies the hierarchical location or address of a file or folder.
An auxiliary software component that extends or enhances the features of other software.
documents formatted for printing are stored in a queue at the speed of the computer, then retrieved and printed at the speed of the printer.
Computer (or the software that runs on it) that acts as a barrier between a network and the Internet by presenting only a single network address to external sites.

Used by System V init to define how the system is booted and what services are available in the running system. In contrast to 'target units', runlevels are numbered; the most commonly known ones are 0 (shutting down the system), 3 (multiuser with network) and 5 (multiuser with network and display manager).

engine at the core of managed code execution. The runtime supplies managed code with services such as cross-language integration, code access security, object lifetime management, and debugging and profiling support.

A standard high-speed parallel interface defined by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). A SCSI interface is used for connecting microcomputers to peripheral devices, such as hard disks and printers, and to other computers and local area networks (LANs).
Procedures involved in preparing a software program or application to operate within a computer or mobile device.
network protocol that allows remote login and other network services to operate securely over an unsecured network.
process of reconciling the differences between data stored in one location and a copy of the same data stored in another location.
formal set of format, timing, sequencing, and error control rules for transferring files to and from a remote computer system running the Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) service.
The process of creating a software-based, virtual representation of a physical IT resource

Allows the running of multiple logical (virtual) Ethernets over one single physical Ethernet. It logically splits the network into different broadcast domains so that packets are only switched between ports that are designated for the same VLAN.
a placeholder represented by a single character, such as an asterisk (*)or ? , which can be interpreted as a number of literal characters or an empty string used in database searches
A local area network (LAN) to which mobile users (clients) can connect and communicate by means of high-frequency radio waves rather than wires. WLANs are specified in the IEEE 802.11 standard
processor architecture Refers to microprocessors that have or emulate the 32-bit Intel processor architecture.
Child snapshot in RADOS block devices.
To form or arrange parts or pieces of something on top of each other.
The maximum number of MDS daemons that will be active for a file system. Similiar to 'level' or 'grade'.
The 'order' in a row of monitors in Ceph monitors. The rank number is determined automatically
To change a system or a data file to make it more current.

A new version of SUSE Products which bears the same product name, including version changes evidenced by a number immediately to either the left or right of the decimal (e.g. SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 9.x to 10.x). If a question arises as to whether a product offering is an Upgrade or a new product, SUSE’s opinion will prevail, provided that SUSE treats the product offering the same for its end users generally
One or more capabilities offered via Cloud Computing invoked using a defined interface.

With the reduction in both cost and size of compute devices, customers are now electing to process and manage data where it is created. A significant amount of data created in near edge, far edge and tiny edge environments are now being processed and managed directly in these environments with no need to move it into a centralized compute environment. Edge Computing provides customers with the compute resources and application stack necessary to process and manage data in these edge environments. As the name implies, edge computing pushes applications, data and computing power (services) away from centralized points to the logical extremes of a network.
degaussing or overwriting information in magnetic or other storage media
To use, or to put into position ready to be used, especially in an effective way.
Putting something into use or action.
To apply patches to the libraries used by a running process, without interrupting it.
Able to be updated with a live patch
A hole in the security of a system deliberately left in place by designers or maintainers.

Capability entries are profile entries for any of the POSIX.1e Linux capabilities allowing a fine-grained control over what a confined process is allowed to do through system calls that require privileges.
A script that runs after the first installation pass has completed but before the first reboot.
A disk drive mechanism for moving the read/write head(s) to the location of the desired track on a disk.

A file packaging tool included with UNIX/Linux for the purpose of assembling a collection of files into one combined file for easier archiving. It was originally designed for tape backup, but today can be used with other storage media. When run by itself, it produces files with a .tar extension.
The name for the Linux equivalent of the Windows Taskbar, i.e., the bar (usually at the bottom of the screen) with icons representing the programs currently running.

public network telecommunications products. A specification from Open Source Development laboratory which defines an industrial strength operating system environment using Linux. Carrier-Grade Linux (CGL) covers hardware, availability, clustering, security, serviceability and performance.
Default account for system administration with the highest access rights on the system
The operating system's command-line interface (CLI) and interpreter for the set of commands that are used to communicate with the system.
A minimal operating system is one that has been stripped of all unnecessary components and provides only the functionality needed for a specific purpose.

a computer user interface that is used to operate software and operating systems while allowing the user to respond to visual prompts by typing single commands into the interface and receiving a reply in the same way.
A corrective fix for a security issue.
Updating all packages of the installed system to the latest state.

A fix or compilation of fixes released by SUSE to correct operation defects (program bugs) in SUSE Products. A patch can contain one or multiple files to replace or enhance existing executables, programs, applications or documents.
A free unix shell and command language that incorporates features from the Korn shell (ksh) and the C shell (csh).

A subunit within a CPU on a single chip that handles the main computational activities of a computer. A CPU may have one or more Cores and therefore be a “Multi-Core CPU” if it has more than one Core.
an AppArmor operating mode for developing profile

shared disk file system for Linux computer clusters. GFS differs from distributed file systems (such as AFS, Coda, or InterMezzo) because it allows all nodes to have direct concurrent access to the same shared block storage. GFS has no disconnected operating-mode, and no client or server roles. All nodes in a GFS cluster function as peers.
To move data from RAM to disk

One of AppArmor's operating modes, the other one being enforcement mode. In complain or learning mode, violations of AppArmor profile rules, such as the profiled program accessing files not permitted by the profile, are detected. The violations are permitted, but also logged. This mode is convenient for developing profiles and is used by the AppArmor tools for generating profiles.
In a menu structure, to open a sub-menu to display its list of items.
The inability of a system or system component to perform a required function within specified limits.

Kerberos tickets are stored in memory. Kerberos is an authentication system developed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and is designed to enable two parties to exchange private information across an otherwise open network. It works by assigning a unique key, called a ticket, to each user that logs on to the network.
to pass (a swipe card) through an electronic reader. By analogy, to pass a finger through a fingerprint reader.
function that works out an installation plan given the set of installed and available packages and a set of dependencies to solve for
The GNOME Desktop Bug Reporting Tool
plan of how to divide a disk or any other storage device into separate parts

Backporting is the act of adapting specific changes from a newer version of software and applying it to an older version. The most commonly used case is fixing security holes in older software components. Usually it is also part of a maintenance model to supply enhancements or (less commonly) new features.
A software patch made up of specific changes, taken from a newer version of a software and applied to an older version of that software, usually for bug fixing purposes.
Installation of a newer major version of a package or distribution, which brings new features.
a dump of the state of an individual process
A name given to a computer file to distinguish it from other files, often containing an extension that classifies it by type.
computer connected to a network on which users of the network can store files.
In an operating system, the overall structure in which files are named, stored, and organized. NTFS, FAT, and FAT32 are types of file systems.

A unique name or label assigned to any device that is connected to a specific computer network. It facilitates the differentiation of different machines or devices connected to the Internet, a network and/or both. Allotted and assigned host names are based on the naming system used.
The arrangement of the functional units of a computer system according to their nature, number and chief characteristics.

An extended support program that offers support and service beyond the general support period. It allows you to maintain your current operating-system version longer, preserving both the stability and security of your data center, as you transition from one service pack version to the next.

A linear ordering of the vertices of a graph. Such that for every directed edge uv from vertex u to vertex v, u comes before v in the ordering. A topological ordering is possible if and only if the graph has no directed cycles, that is, if it is a directed acyclic graph (DAG).
On-premises software and technology is housed within the physical location of an enterprise, rather than in the cloud or on hosted servers in a remote facility.
In the Common Desktop Environment (CDE), the permission granted to a user or group of users to perform various operations on a file or folder.
Designates an unexpected or irregular behaviour of software or hardware.

On a computer monitor, a color display in which each pixel (or smallest point of color) is described by 4 bits of information. (One bit is either a 1 or a 0; 4-Bit color can be thought of as one of these two numbers taken to the fourth power; thus 2^4 = 16 possible colors.) The color of a pixel on a computer display is commonly expressed as some amount of red, green, and blue. Greater numbers of combinations of these amounts require more processing power on the part of the computer. At 4 bits per pixel, a total of 16 colors can be described and displayed. (Some programs allow you to specify which colors can be included in that palette.) See also 1-bit color.

A key, or combination of keys, on a keyboard that can be used to perform a particular operation. For example, in many applications pressing ctrl+a (holding down the control key and pressing letter ‘a’) is ‘select all’. Other examples are ctrl+c (copy), ctrl+x (cut), and ctrl+v (paste).
Centralized identity management is a system that unifies and enables the management and control of user identities, access privileges and other resources across technology and enterprise boundaries.
In programming a data type defined by the operations that can be performed on objects of that type rather than by the properties of the objects themselves.
A hardware device that speeds or enhances the operation of one or more subsystems, leading to improved program performance.
A tag in an HTML document that defines a section of text, an icon, or other element as a link to another element in the document or to another document or file.

The information upon which policies make decisions. In the same way that employees are limited in their abilities based upon their knowledge, Policies are limited in their decision making abilities based upon the quality and quantity of information at hand.
A college course, often in a specialized field of study, that is designed to give students supervised practical application of a previously studied theory. Practicums are common for education majors.

an interface description language for defining data structures that can be serialized and deserialized in a standard, cross-platform way. It's broadly used in telecommunications and computer networking, and especially in cryptography.
a component within an application that controls the communication method to other devices

The Linux Integration Components for Hyper-V provide synthetic device driver support for Linux operating systems, enabling the same high performance expected of Windows virtual machines for Linux virtual machines.

Industry specifications often insist that the firm maintain a secure network, protect stored data, implement strong access management measures, regularly monitor and test networks, and maintain a comprehensive information security policy.

On a computer monitor, a color display in which each pixel (or smallest point of color) is described by 1 bit of information. (One bit is either a 1 or a 0; 1-Bit color can be thought of as one of these two numbers taken to the first power; thus 21 = 2 possible colors.) The color of a pixel on a computer display is commonly expressed as some amount of red, green, and blue. Greater numbers of combinations of these amounts require more processing power on the part of the computer. At 1 bit per pixel, a total of only two colors (typically black and white, or any other two colors) can be described and displayed.

tig.term: 启用加密法的应用程序

termEntry.descrip: A solution that allows individuals and businesses easily conduct transactions while protecting the privacy and security of vital identity information.

The preview assigned to a PostScript image so the user can view the art file inside of another software program while it is being displayed online. For example, you must assign a PC preview to an image that you create in Adobe Illustrator on the Macintosh if you wish to view that image on the PC. A 1-bit preview is black and white.
One of the two types of NICI. The other is called Exportable NICI. (128 bit) This product is only available to U.S. and Canada customers. It is not available for export.

An object in the NDS tree whose purpose is to provide a highest point to access different Country and Organization objects, and to allow trustee assignments granting rights to the entire NDS tree. Country, Organization, and Alias objects can be created at the [Root] object. The [Root] object is a place holder; it contains no information. Sometimes called a directory root.

The mechanisms for permitting or limiting entry to a computer network. Access control manages user access by requiring authentication of the user's identity or membership in a predefined group; it is typically used by system administrators for controlling access to servers, directories or other network resources.
A "C" in a circle (©), followed by the year of publication and the name of the person claiming the copyright.
A recovery operation after an abend.
A hardware device or a computer's software that acts as a communication hub for users of a wireless device to connect to a wired LAN.
A software module that allows NDPS clients to send jobs to printers that are not NDPS aware, and to access printers and print systems that require jobs to be placed in queues.
ABR An Open Shortest Path First (OSPF) router used to connect administrative domains (called areas) to a central backbone area on a large internetwork.
A system or program failure, or operator action that causes a program, application subsystem, or transaction program to end unsuccessfully.
A file system right that grants the ability to change the trustee assignments and inherited rights filter of a directory or file.

The permissions that are granted to a user, or to an application, to read, write and erase files in the computer. Access rights can be tied to a particular client or server, to folders within that machine or to specific programs and data files.
Account management is the business practice of retaining and growing relationships with existing customers.
The operations that an operating system can perform, such as read, write, append, lock and execute (sometimes abbreviated RWALX).
A server name that includes a list of all domains in the path from the local domain to the root.

an attribute on the object that is being accessed. Each ACL value specifies who can access the object; what type of rights the accessor has been granted; and whether children of the accessor inherit those rights. When an object has been granted rights to another object, the accessor is called a trustee of the target object.
In the Common Desktop Environment CDE, the name of a Terminal Options dialog box used to enable or disable an escape sequence for switching to 132-column format.
The maximum data rate of a channel between a user site and a network, as defined by the bandwidth of the access link available for data transmission.
IT organizations view and analyze BSM information using a combination of built-in analytics, such as impact and root cause, integrated into a rolebased, intuitive and interactive dashboard interface.

A package management system is a collection of tools to automate the process of installing, upgrading, configuring, and removing software packages from a computer. Distributions of Linux and other Unix-like systems typically consist of hundreds or even thousands of distinct software packages.
To accept or admit that something exists, is true, or is real.

Accessibility features are various options that exist within products that allow a user to adjust the settings to their personal needs. Products can come with various accessibility features that can adjust to the individual’s visual, mobility, hearing, language, and learning needs. Accessibility features allow individuals with disabilities to use products that may not other wise be useful. They also serve as a piece of assistive technology because adjustments are being made to help the individual.
A person who is responsible for the upkeep, configuration, and reliable operation of computer systems, especially multiuser computers, such as servers.
A special user account for general system administration such as in networks and databases

The root file system is the top of the hierarchical file tree. It contains the files and directories critical for system operation, including the device directory and programs for booting the system. The root file system also contains mount points where file systems can be mounted to connect to the root file system hierarchy.
A command-line interface that allows a user to interact with the operating system.
A short version and unique identifier of the repository name for use in repository handling commands

As an urgent measure against issues that need to be fixed immediately and outside of the normal development flow. A coldfix requires users to log out of the software while entire systems need to be rebooted for fixes to go into effect.
A feature that allows replacing a component in a system without shutting down or interrupting its operation. Commonly used with RAID devices. For non-RAID devices use hotplug
The process of replacing or adding components to a computer system without stopping, shutting down, or rebooting the system. Commonly used with RAID devices. For non-RAID devices use hot plugging.
Isolated Linux systems (processes or groups of processes) which share a single Linux kernel.

Refers to the distribution channel of a product, from its sourcing, to its delivery to the end consumer (also known as the value chain). The supply chain is typically comprised of multiple companies who are increasingly coordinating activities via an extranet or using other IT solution.
A paradigm for enabling network access to a scalable and elastic pool of shareable physical or virtual resources with selfservice provisioning and administration on-demand.

A product which requires another product as a foundation to be operational. Examples are: SLES (as foundation) and SLE HA (as Extension), SLES (as foundation) and SMT (Subscription Management Tool as Extension), SLES (as foundation) and SLE HA and Geo SLE HA (as Extension).
A disk as seen by the operating system and is written to by SUSE Enterprise Storage. This can be a physical disk or a partition of an NVMe.

A method of allocating space on mass-storage devices that is more flexible than conventional partitioning schemes. In particular, a volume manager can concatenate, stripe together or otherwise combine partitions into larger virtual ones that administrators can re-size or move, potentially without interrupting system use. Volume management represents just one of many forms of storage virtualization; its implementation takes place in a layer in the device-drive stack of an OS (as opposed to within storage devices or in a network).
To stop a program or function before it has finished naturally. It refers to both requested and unexpected terminations.
Software hackers, which perform illegal activities for financial gain, the challenge, or simply for the fun of it.

Software hackers which stand up for what’s right and protect civilians and organizations at large by finding and reporting vulnerabilities in systems before the black hats do. They usually work for organizations and take roles such as a Cybersecurity Engineer, Penetration Tester, Security Analyst, CISO (Chief Information Security Officer), and other security positions.

a basic access control mechanism that allows through all elements (email addresses, users, passwords, URLs, IP addresses, domain names, file hashes, etc.), except those explicitly mentioned. Those items on the list are denied access. Denylist is the reverse of allowlist.
A randomly picked value that is just used for demonstrating.
An activity, person, group, etc. that is not covered by a new law because of a grandfather clause.
The amount of work done by one person in one hour.
A metaphor used in computing to refer to a system with a single store of record and a set of replicas which maintain copies of the original data.
The original thread of code for a project’s codebase. The main branch of a project is considered as the default branch.
Permanently connected pieces of equipment which cannot be easily removed.
A basic test to quickly evaluate whether a claim or the result of a calculation can possibly be true.
Devices or processes controlled by another device or process.
Someone whose job is to manage a website
A method of software testing that tests internal structures or workings of an application, as opposed to its functionality.

a list or register of entities that are being provided a particular privilege, service, mobility, access or recognition. Entities on the list will be accepted, approved and/or recognized. Allowlist is the reverse of denylist.

For issues not covered by a support level agreement, SUSE might still decide to try and mitigate the issue, but only if it does not require a significant effort. In that case, the usual SLAs, KPIs and support levels do not apply.

A strategic approach to business marketing based on account awareness in which an organization considers and communicates with individual prospect or customer accounts as markets of one. Account-based marketing is typically employed in enterprise-level sales organizations.
A common source code for a large number of programs and modules to reduce complexity at all levels of application development and operation.
Defines the terms under which intellectual property has been contributed to a company/project, typically software under an open source license.

An infrastructure-centric approach where the main focus is monitoring and managing of infrastructure resources such as virtual machines, storage, network etc. It can be used indirectly to manage applications by combining some orchestration capabilities as part of the platform.
To withdraw official support for or discourage the use of (something, such as a software product) in favor of a newer or better alternative
Refers to the act of eliminating a file, text, or another object from the computer hard drive or other media
A code that is used to register or activate a software application.
a technology that facilitates fast data transmission at a high bandwidth on existing copper wire telephone lines to homes and businesses
a plug-and-play portable storage device that uses flash memory.
firmware used to provide runtime services for operating systems and programs and to perform hardware initialization during the booting process
A combination of several network interfaces into one bond.
Combination of two or more network interfaces into a single bonded device.

The combination or aggregation of two or more network connections to form a single channel with a bandwidth greater than the standard channel bandwidth. For the new approach, please see network teaming.
Something that has been packaged to run within a container.

The ability of computer hardware or software to ensure data integrity when hardware failures occur. Fault-tolerant features appear in many server operating systems and include mirrored volumes, RAID-5 volumes, and server clusters.
In distributed processing, the distribution of activity across two or more servers in order to avoid overloading any one with too many requests from users.
Network bonding combines two or more network interfaces into a single bonded device to increase bandwidth and/or provide redundancy.
An interface providing access to a network system or enabling communications between protocol layers. The interface can be a physical device or a piece of software.

The combination or aggregation of two or more network connections to form a single channel with a bandwidth greater than the standard channel bandwidth. It supplies a set of small kernel modules responsible for providing an interface for teamd instances. Everything else is handled in user space. This is different from the original bonding implementation, which contains all of its functionality exclusively in the kernel.

The evaluation of work by one or more people of similar competence to the producers of the work constituting a form of self-regulation by qualified members of a profession within the relevant field to maintain standards of quality, improve performance, and provide credibility.
A type of deployment that uses a customized file called profile which includes a description of the system to install. Also see script-based deployment.
A type of deployment that uses a plain shell script which enables custom pre-deployment workflows. Also see profile-based deployment.
A static report that contains data captured at a specific point in time.

Timers are systemd unit files whose name ends in .timer that control .service files or events. Timers can be used as an alternative to cron. Timers have built-in support for calendar time events, monotonic time events, and can be run asynchronously.
a tunable value used to control and customize the behavior and functionality of the kernel
a list of computer hardware (typically including many types of peripheral devices) that is compatible with a particular operating system or device management software
A file that defines the parameters, options, settings and preferences for a piece of software.
a protocol designed to access and maintain information directories
a software component that can run containers on a host operating system
an exit code indicates the response from the command or a script after execution
the final stages of a product's existence

A type of performance measurement. KPIs evaluate the success of an organization or of a particular activity in which it engages and are typically quantifiable and objective criterion measuring success.
an advanced AI model trained on amounts of text data to understand and generate human-like text. Can perform tasks like translation, summarization and answering questions.
practices and technologies used to ensure the security and integrity of software and hardware components throughout the supply chain
refers to applications or services that are built and designed specifically for cloud environments, leveraging cloud computing principles and technologies
a menu typically placed in a top corner of a graphical user interface with the icon consisting of three horizontal bars, also known as the collapsed menu icon
an icon used to open a menu with additional options, often located at the top-right or top-left of the screen or window
a Linux deployment with a read-only host operating system that can only be modified through new image deployments, ensuring consistency while still allowing workload changes in designated partitions

System where configuration changes are treated as transactions that are atomic and reversible. Changes are grouped together and can be rolled back, ensuring that the system can be reinstated into a previously defined working state. Transactional systems require that package dependencies are solved by the package manager and thus do not guarantee that the resolution is exactly the same for all systems, but ensure a consistent solution and a fallback.
System to define the desired state of the system.
Any company that provides Internet access to consumers and businesses.

A contract that standardizes the documentation that a software licensor signs to allow a licensee to use their property. Software companies that frequently license their software out or licensors and licensees who frequently work together and want to simplify the contract drafting process. By using a generalized form that is later personalized, the pair is able to save money and time.
A commercial document issued by a buyer to a seller, indicating types, quantities, and agreed prices for products or services required.
value of products/services delivered to customers (top line)

Data structure on a Unix file system that store basic information about a regular file, directory or other file system object. They store all attributes of a file system object (like user and group ownership, read, write or execute permissions), except file name and contents.

A limit set by a system administrator that restricts certain aspects of file system usage on modern operating systems. The function of using disk quotas is to allocate limited disk space in a reasonable way.

Defines a warning level at which users are informed that they are nearing their limit. Administrators may urge the users to clean up and reduce their data on the partition. The soft quota limit is normally lower than the hard quota limit.
Defines the limit at which write requests are denied. When the hard quota is reached, no more data can be stored and applications may crash.
Defines the time between the overflow of the soft quota and a warning being issued. Normally set to a rather low value of one or several hours.
a subset of a computer's hardware resources, virtualized as a separate computer
a special type of boot sector at the very beginning of partitioned computer mass storage devices like fixed disks or removable drives
the critical process of loading the initial set of instructions into the main memory of a computer during its startup or booting sequence
a 12-digit hexadecimal number assigned to each device connected to the network
an archive file that contains an identical copy (or image) of data found on an optical disc, like a CD or DVD

The largest allowed packet size in bytes that can be communicated in a single network layer transaction. A higher MTU brings higher bandwidth efficiency. However, large packets can block up a slow interface for some time, increasing the lag for further packets.
a type of secondary storage device that supports direct access to stored data, as opposed to sequential access, which is slower and less efficient
Each repository provides files describing the content of the repository (package names, versions, etc.). These repository description files are downloaded to a local cache that is used by YaST.

A single snapshot is created every hour. Using the YaST OS installation method (default), timeline snapshots are enabled, except for the root file system. You can configure timeline snapshots to be taken at different intervals: hourly, daily, weekly, monthly and yearly. Old snapshots are automatically deleted. By default, the first snapshot of the last ten days, months and years is kept.

Whenever one or more packages are installed with Zypper or YaST, three installation snapshots are created. In case an important system component such as the kernel has been installed, the snapshot pair is marked as important. Old snapshots are automatically deleted. Installation snapshots are enabled by default.

Whenever you make changes to the system using Zypper or YaST, a pair of snapshots is created: one prior to the system change (“pre”) and the other one after the system change (“post”). Old snapshots are automatically deleted. Administration snapshots are enabled by default.
a set of policies, processes, software and hardware used to create, manage, distribute, use, store and revoke digital certificates
a protocol that provides secure communication between client-server applications. TLS is the successor to the SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) protocol.
Process of applying patches to the libraries used by a running process without interrupting them.

Available in SUSE Linux Enterprise Server as a technology preview, for updating SLES when the root file system is read-only. Transactional updates are atomic (all updates are applied only if all updates succeed) and support rollbacks. It does not affect a running system, as no changes are activated until after the system is rebooted. As reboots are disruptive, the administrator must decide if a reboot is more expensive than disturbing running services.

Used by systemd to define how the system is booted and what services are available in the running system. In contrast to 'runlevels', target units are named rather than numbered and serve specific purposes. For example, the targets local-fs.target and swap.target mount local file systems and swap spaces. It remains fully compatible with the runlevel concept.

The most recent version of the Internet Protocol (IP), the communications protocol that provides an identification and location system for computers on networks and routes traffic across the Internet. IPv6 was developed by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) to deal with the long-anticipated problem of IPv4 address exhaustion, and was intended to replace IPv4.
partial unit files that override only specific settings of the unit file. Drop-ins have higher precedence over main configuration files.
a data type that has one of two possible values (usually denoted true and false) which is intended to represent the two truth values of logic and Boolean algebra
a group of components that provides remote users with a point of access to a network

a complex set of electronic circuitry that runs the machine’s operating system and apps. The CPU interprets, processes and executes instructions, most often from the hardware and software programs running on the device.

a configuration description for a single system. It consists of sets of resources with properties including support for complex structures such as lists, records, trees and large embedded or referenced objects.

the hardware in a computing device that provides temporary storage for the operating system (OS), software programs and any other data in current use, so they are quickly available to the device's processor
a type of semiconductor memory that is typically used for the data or program code needed by a computer processor to function
the chronology of the origin, development, ownership, location and changes to a system or system component and associated data
to boot or to load a program into a computer using a much smaller initial program to load in the desired program, which is usually an operating system

the concept of gaining an understanding of the behavior and performance of applications and systems. Observability starts by collecting system telemetry data, such as logs, metrics and traces. More important is how that telemetry is analyzed to diagnose issues, understand the interconnectivity of dependencies, and ensure reliability.

the automatic measurement and wireless transmission of data from remote sources.
