Software developers and IT administrators use telemetry to remotely monitor the health, security and performance of applications and application components in real time. They use telemetry to measure startup and processing times, crashes, user behavior and resource use, and to assess the state of a system.
a legal contract between a software supplier and a customer or end user
a code segment capable of dynamic loading and unloading within the kernel as needed
a standardized packaging method for kernel modules that guarantees compatibility with kernel updates and proper handling during system upgrades
IP masquerading is a process where one computer acts as an IP gateway for a network.
a network security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules
To change the apparent root directory for the current running process and its children.
characterizing a system, interface or resource that allows simultaneous reading and writing of data
describing a system, interface or component that possesses both read and write capabilities, though not necessarily operating simultaneously
A subset of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to produce text, images, videos, or other forms of data.
a caching strategy in which data is first written to a cache and later written to the primary storage (such as main memory or disk) only when necessary

refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines that are designed to learn and solve problems like humans. Enables computers to understand language, make decisions and improve from experience.
a security measure where a computer network is physically isolated from unsecured networks, including the public Internet

describing a system, network or device that is physically or logically isolated from unsecured networks, including the public Internet, as a security measure to prevent unauthorized access or data breaches
a practice allowing users to provide their own SSL/TLS certificates for securing communications instead of using default or auto-generated ones
an entity that issues digital certificates to verify the identity of certificate holders and ensure secure communications
a prompting technique that guides AI models to break down complex problems into step-by-step reasoning processes, improving response accuracy and transparency
the maximum amount of text (tokens) that an AI model can process at once, including both the input prompt and generated response
extensions of the Kubernetes API that allow users to define custom resources and their controllers in a Kubernetes cluster
a numerical representation of data (text, images, etc.) in a high-dimensional space that captures semantic relationships and enables AI models to process information effectively
the practice of managing and provisioning infrastructure through machine-readable definition files rather than manual processes
the process of using a trained AI model to make predictions or generate outputs based on new input data
the learned parameters of an AI model that determine how it processes inputs and generates outputs. These weights are adjusted during training to optimize model performance.
A process of automatically generating human-like text from structured data or other forms of input. Designed to convert raw data into coherent and meaningful language easily understood by humans.
A process AI uses to analyze and understand the meaning of the input query.
a security vulnerability where malicious inputs attempt to override or bypass an AI model's system prompt or safety constraints
a technique to reduce AI model size and computational requirements by converting model parameters to lower precision formats while maintaining acceptable performance
a technique that enhances AI responses by retrieving relevant information from a knowledge base before generating answers, improving accuracy and reducing hallucinations
a security model that restricts system access based on roles assigned to users, managing permissions and authorization in Kubernetes clusters
the basic unit of text processing in AI models, representing whole words, subwords, characters or symbols. Models break text into tokens to analyze input and generate output.
Describes the concept of preventing access to a shared resource by isolated or failing cluster members.
A graphical control element comprising a vertically stacked list of items, such as labels or thumbnails. Each item can be "expanded" or "collapsed" to reveal the content associated with that item.
the process of removing personal identifiers from a data set
the process of analyzing activities and the effect that a business disruption might have on them
a system providing a way to capture the principal characteristics of a vulnerability and produce a numerical score reflecting its severity

European Union regulation on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Directive 95/46/EC (Data Protection Directive)
authentication system that requires more than one distinct authentication factor for successful authentication
a set of processes of formal management of privacy as defined in industry standard ISO/IEC 27701:2019
a set of processes of formal management of information security as defined in industry standard ISO/IEC 27001:2013
the process of reverting a system, application or database to a previous stable state, typically to recover from errors, failed updates or unwanted changes
weakness in an information system, system security procedures, internal controls, or implementation that could be exploited or triggered by a threat source
a pre-release version of software made accessible to a limited set of customers, partners or members of the upstream community. It is typically feature-complete but may contain known or unknown bugs.

describes a product that is considered complete from an engineering or technical perspective, with all core features implemented and tested. However, it has not yet been released to the market, as additional preparation—such as marketing, documentation, legal review, or support readiness—is still in progress.
The first public communication about a new product or major release, typically announced at an event or through a press release.
A general method for making a program or other work free, and requiring all modified and extended versions of the program to be free as well

A specialized database optimized to store, manage and efficiently query high-dimensional vector embeddings, enabling advanced AI applications like semantic search, recommendation systems and machine learning tasks that require complex similarity comparisons
where the user knows the details of the hardware to be deployed to and has direct access to the out-of-band management interface to orchestrate and automate the entire provisioning process.
Actions that can be scheduled to apply the highstate or an arbitrary set of custom states to clients on a specified schedule.

A Kubernetes controller capable of performing upgrades over the following SUSE Edge platform components: Operating System (SUSE Linux Micro), Kubernetes (K3s & RKE2), Additional components (Rancher, Elemental, SUSE Security, etc.).
A separate database in SUSE Multi-Linux Manager (especially in hub scenarios for large deployments) from which spacewalk-report extracts data, updated by a scheduled task.
The task engine in SUSE Multi-Linux Manager responsible for running scheduled jobs like repository metadata regeneration, cleanup tasks, and client check-ins.
A SUSE Multi-Linux Manager configuration for environments where it is not possible to connect the SUSE Multi-Linux Manager server to the internet.
A component or process in SUSE Multi-Linux Manager, run by the gatherer-matcher-default task, that collects data from virtual hosts configured in Virtual Host Managers.
A feature in SUSE Multi-Linux Manager that allows scheduling actions to occur during a defined period, preventing certain restricted actions outside this window.
Repositories created on the SUSE Multi-Linux Manager, sometimes manually for end-of-life products, used for client registration and initial setup.

a concise manual that guides users through the initial setup or basic use of an IT product. It typically covers essential installation steps, configuration, and first-use instructions to help users become productive quickly.
a type of instructional content that provides step-by-step guidance on completing a specific task or using a particular feature of a product

A desktop operating system, built for system administrators and software developers (limited) targeted at physical workstation deployments. The SUSE Linux Enterprise Workstation Extension enhances other SUSE Linux Enterprise products with desktop productivity tools and is primarily targeted for VDI scenarios.
